reviewText: I don't understand how this can be free. Surely it must have cost a lot to make?\n\nAnyway, it's a 15 minute experience where you get to make a single decision and then shoot some drones. reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Divergent series you should probably give this a try, otherwise, just pass it by.

Pros:It's free
If you're a fan of the series I'm sure it's really cool to be in that universe.
Same voice actors as the movies.
The shooting is fun.
When talking to a character, they will actually look at you.
Neutral:It's a quick experience, which would make it good for demoing the Vive (assuming you don't have issues). However, it also leaves more to be desired.
While characters do look at you while reciting dialog, outside of that they don't interact at all. Like if you get right up in someones face they don't care at all and just continue on their scripted animations.
Cons:I had lots of edge artifacts (Like when you play a game with no anti-aliasing on).
FPS was also an issue, any moving objects seemed to lag about every 3 seconds or so.
Vive controllers were assigned to the wrong hands. I checked the home screen, and I did have them in the correct hands. I also tried the game three different time. It happened every time. Also after I closed the game and launched a different game the controllers were in the correct hand.
Poor animation transitions. It's a bit immersion breaking when a character suddenly goes rigid, then goes into it's next animation.
On two different runthroughs I had black screen crashes where I had to restart my computer. No other VR experience has done this to me.
For what it is I can't harp on it too much. It's a free, quick experience to show off the Vives capabilites. Bonus if they're a fan. But I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend it.

Rig: Intel Core i7-5930K, 32GB DDR4 2800, (x2) EVGA GTX 980 SC (one dedicated to PhysX), 500GB Samsung 840 Evo SSD, Win 10.

Update: After disabling SLI and setting my secondary card to only PhysX my screen and object jitter completely went away. No black screens since the switch. Edge artifacts are still present however (no tweakable AA settings that I could found), and in-game hands are still flipped sometimes too.

Even after I now have it running properly I'm still not going to recommend it. I will admit that I'm much closer to neutral on it now. However, I'm still sticking by that unless you're a fan, it isn't a must play" kind of experience."
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is a must play" free game. This game shows a lot of potential in what other VR games can bring to the table. I don't really care about the graphics quality at all. It could be better and I am sure if this was a full title it would be better rendered. Other than that it is awesome to be in the "movie" so to speak. I am not really a fan of the series but the overall gameplay and game concept is what I want out of VR. I am there right in the middle of everything. Any negatives in VR right now is just plain stupid in my opinion. The only thing I won't tolerate is blocky old school looking games because we have graphics cards that can do better now.Overall I say try it. It is free. Any free VR game is worth trying so that developers have feedback from us: the VR community. I played this game with the VIVE and it was just short and fun to be in. Yes we can say "be in" now. We are actually immersed in games now. Yay !!!\n\nOh yeah it will act funny if your space is not quite big enough or won't play at all so make sure your play area meets specs. I actually cheated and measured my space a little larger than it was so I can reach over my desk tops for extra space and play the game. Trust me I have a large area already so I was surprised that they required such a large area. Enjoy."

reviewText: I normally get easily sick in the real world, and never get sick in - well done - room-scale Vive experiences. I was very, very surprised and pleased that this experience did not make me sick. There is movement in an elevator, and there is a lot of movement staying on the roof of a running vehicle. The experience is short but well done.

reviewText: This game is a glimpse into a AAA game that utilises room scale perfectly.... problem is, even with a GTX780ti overclocked it runs at frame rates that are motion sickness inducing!!! Would love to see this turned into a full game, designed to run smoothly on gtx 980 or equivalent.\n\nQuitting this game made Steam VR turn into a judder fest, that left me feeling sick for an hour afterwards... the first VR game to do so.

reviewText:
Product received for free

A nice little tech demo for the Vive!
Besides some graphical issues (artifacts) and a turret control that needs some getting used to, it is quite good. Only to short if you liked the books and movies :)

I really hope that in the future we will see more interactive VR movies. Just imagine Mass Effect without the boring elements and only the mainquest with you in the middle, making a few decisions which will change how the VR-movie goess along and interacting every now and then.

reviewText:
Very amazing experience. Quickly felt immsersed.

Only the gaming part itself wasn't so well designed. Turrent movement wasn't intuitive, enemy drones weren't dangerous.

I also looovvvvvvvvvvvvved the fact, that all 3 chracters are actually actors.
Shailene Woodley and Ansel Elgort created The Fault in Our Stars".
One of the most amazing parts was actually the just credits scene were I could move up very close to the figures.
They felt almost real.
Shailene Woodley is looking directly into your eyes and smiling at you. Extremely well designed facial expressions. (only the faces were a little blurry) Funnily I was smiling back. And maybe waving my hand
date: knowing they wouldn't see it but whatever...\n\nOh and another little weird thing was
recommended: the persons in the experience are looking too tall. They felt even taller than me
hoursPlayed: while myself being pretty tall already."
